The Dash CSS Robot challenge was a lot of fun! Noticed that I had to include the background-size again (75px 150px) in the animation keyframes selector as well...else would get a single red blinking light instead of matching against the 2 white lights. Pretty nifty CSS animation features!

I am in the challenge 5 building a small business website. Can I get a hint at what I need code i need to write for this challenge: "Wrap the rest of each menu description inside small tags".
<small></small>
It's a formatting tag.
So, it'll look something like this <small> menu description here </small>

@iyeager2004 here is what I coded. Didn't work:

Welsh onion soko $14
Mustard sierra leone bologi kale chard beet greens black-eyed pea sorrel amaranth garlic tigernut spring onion summer purslane asparagus lentil.
@Sonju Just wrap the text in the <small> tags. <small> is a formatting shortcut for text, like using <h1>.

I am I replacing

with
nope. Ok. I'll keep at it. even googled to fry to find answer. I'll read my CSS book

Don't replace. Just put it inside. The

puts the text into a paragraph the makes the text look small.
put it inside the div

Welsh onion soko $14
Mustard sierra leone bologi kale chard beet greens black-eyed pea sorrel amaranth garlic tigernut spring onion summer purslane asparagus lentil.
not outside it
yes like that ^
<div class="first”> this is for styling in your css, <small> is html text styling so should be right around the text you wish to make smaller
OMG.. thanks! what does the <small></small> element function as?

<small> is a css tag. Later you'll learn that you can make the text wrapped in <small> tags be whatever you want, In fact, you can change it based on the browser size, so you can have small be one thing on a computer screen and something completely different on a phone's screen.
Cool @iyeager2004 . Thanks a lot for taking time to explain it. Thanks 2 @odrisck you rock 2.

i wrote the function incorrect?
yes, functions are either `function name(params) or var name = function(params)`

It looks like both our event handler on .photos li elements are exactly the same! Let's go ahead and refactor these into a new function named showPhotos and change our event handlers to reference that instead.
you need to put
$(this).find("span").slideToggle();
into the function
that's all?
then change the event handlers instead of calling a whole function to call showPhotos
and reference your function in the event
ahhh! Thank you!
You have a few types of functions..
instead of
$(".photos").on("mouseenter", "li", function() { $(this).find("span").slideToggle();
well there’s also anonymous functions
put $(".photos").on("mousenter","li",showPhotos)

Hey all. Anyone know if I can always leave off the bling on the .appendTo selector in the following code: ``` $(".target:nth-child(2)").clone().appendTo("#location2"); ``` It works correctly in the jQuery exercises, but the solution includes bling on the location2 selector.
there are more than one way to do it. If your solution works its fine
Thanks

http://api.jquery.com/appendTo/ looks like one example of using bling on appendTo is something like $( "h2" ).appendTo( $( ".container" ) ); The jquery documentation says doing it this way will actually move the element around the DOM, instead of cloning it like in your example.

Hey all. Anyone know if I can always leave off the bling on the .appendTo selector in the following code: ``` $(".target:nth-child(2)").clone().appendTo("#location2"); ``` It works correctly in the jQuery exercises, but the solution includes bling on the location2 selector.
there are more than one way to do it. If your solution works its fine
Thanks

http://api.jquery.com/appendTo/ looks like one example of using bling on appendTo is something like $( "h2" ).appendTo( $( ".container" ) ); The jquery documentation says doing it this way will actually move the element around the DOM, instead of cloning it like in your example.

@Maximization Why always `===` instead of `==`? I was under the impression it's exactly the same thing.

you can probably stop it crashing by only checking up to the square root of the number

@PrimitiveLogic one thing related to primes, you can stop checking if a number is a prime at its square root, that is, if `x = 101` and you've checked against prime number 7, which is the last prime lower than `sqrt(x)=10` then you can assume that x is a prime number
Hmm, right now my mind couldn't comprehend anything you just wrote.
@PrimitiveLogic because `==` and `===` have a different meaning in JS, `===` tests for deep equality that is, not only if the two values match but they if their object representation also matches

``` [] + {} => "[object Object]" ```
@teddy-error oh right, if you do ['1'] + ['1'] it makes sense
it's taking the contents of the area, which is an empty string and adding it to another empty string apparently
area = array
what even
well it does automatic type conversion I suppose. it looks pretty bizarre though
why would someone concatenating arrays want the type converted to string!
well try this one
oops, forgot i can't do backticks on irc
I have no explanation for the {} + {} . that's just weird
okay so i guess never trust list literals
well {} is an empty object, if you add another emopty object to it you're going to get NaN
because an object
plus an object
is obviously NaN
Well it'd be okay if an array + an array would also be NaN but since that's not true it does seem inconsistent
not really but what do you expect? NaO (not an object) does not exist in JS
like, a TypeError
{} + {} will result in a false statement that JS decides to be
both are the same type so that's perfectly fine
the `+` expression either concatenates or adds both sides
Actually, {} + {} returne objectObject objectObject in node, so the NaN looks like a chrome thing
if it has two empty objects and it's returning NaN then it obviously can't concatenate any strings and it doesn't have any numbers to work with
why would you worry that much about it anyway, adding two empty objects who does that
said the developers of Javascript

@wdgreg it's because {} doesn't have any way to return a proper value for using in the expression and NaN is kind of a catchall "oh crap bro, you gave me data I can't use for what you want me to use it for" ... for a more detailed explanation http://www.2ality.com/2012/01/object-plus-object.html
node returns something that makes more sense though. it doesn't really matter but NaN does seem weird, lemme read that link first though :)
Ohhh okay that link explains it entirely!

for those interested who didn't read the link: the first {} in {}+{} is ignored because it looks like a code block and then +{} remains and + will convert the empty object into a number which is then of course NaN
